data.title: The AAT(SA) Accounting Qualification
data.body:
The AAT(SA) qualification can enable your career in finance and accounting and help you make a truly positive contribution to your business, department or unit.

Professional skills to be proud of

Our qualification is based on real-world knowledge, supported by in-depth expertise.

Its value is so widely known that firms like Vodafone, Telkom, and Toyota actively seek AAT qualified staff for their knowledge, skills, diligence and enthusiasm.

Open to everyone

AAT enables you to choose how, when and where you study. Training is flexible and open to everyone.  You may be heading for your first job in accounting and finance, seeking a change of career, or already work in the industry.

signpost.title: Find out what you'll learn at Level 3 - Certificate: Accounting Technician
Find out what you'll learn at Level 4 - FET Certificate: Accounting Technician
Find out what you'll learn at Level 5 - Certificate: Accounting

data.title: What you'll learn at level 3
data.body:
Level 3 - Certificate: Accounting Technician covers a range of basic accounting practices and techniques; from costing and double-entry bookkeeping to computerised accounting. It's ideal if you’re new to working in finance or you’re looking to expand and develop your foundation knowledge and skills.

Topics covered

signpost.title: Download our list of AAT(SA) approved training providers to find one near you (PDF)

tabs.title: Basic Accounting I
tabs.content:
• Principles and procedures related to processing business transactions, financial documents and payments for customers and suppliers.
  • Developing skills in processing ledger transactions and preparing an initial trial balance.

tabs.title: Basic Accounting II
tabs.content:
• Maintenance and reconciliation of a cash book by accurately entering receipts and payments, balancing off the book and reconciling with bank statements.
  • Knowledge and understanding of the UK banking system and related organisational activities.
  • Petty cash transactions and the importance of the Journal as a primary accounting record.
  • Maintaining control over debtors and creditors, aided by preparation and use of debtor and creditor control accounts.
  • Non-standard bookkeeping transactions and double-entry bookkeeping records.

tabs.title: Work effectively in accounting and finance
tabs.content:
• Developing transferable skills and effective working in an accounting environment.
  • Teamwork skills and the ability to work independently.
  • Demonstrating workplace-ready standards of literacy and numeracy.
